comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: It seems an unlikely location for the anvil?  They generally worked on the metal while it was hot and that shoe looks cold in the tongs.  Nicely taken shot and I'd be willing to bet that the Sergt. is the man at the anvil!
comment.authorname: swordscookie

comment.author: 53227388@N00
comment._content: Apparently, farrier's anvils were also used for "cold shaping" of horse shoes. So sayeth the all-knowing internet. butlerhorseshoeingschools.com/2010/08/how-to-choose-and-u... Which is not to say the shot wasn't posed either, mind you.
comment.authorname: Woesinger

comment.author: 72025404@N08
comment._content: so interesting. I wonder that all of them might have gone to the first world war, a few years later... it's incredible to look at these pictures and think about the historical context!

comment._content: The location on the map is wrong I'm afraid, the Artillery/Cavalry Barracks was at the corner of Cannon Street and Blakes Lane and unfortunately no longer exists.

comment.author: 99684904@N00
comment._content:
Note the very short haircuts, very very very common for men in the first half of the 20th century... not go watch pretty much any movie about this era and compare the hairstyles of the actors with the ones in photos of that time...
Wrong, wrong, wrong!
comment.authorname: Jo Hedwig Teeuwisse

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: Sergeant Murray is probably a farrier sergeant or possibly a farrier Staff Sergeant. The 1911 Census shows a farrier staff sergeant at number 3 on the form H, barrack return, unfortunately initials only but the last name begins with M, www.census.nationalarchives.ie/reels/nai003506038/
